Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Immigration and the Politics of Citizenship and Race

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will examine issues related to the principle of jus soli citizenship, which is the practice of unconditional birthright citizenship for people born in a country, a practice found in the United States and about 30 other nations, mostly in the Americas. The project will focus on the geography of political and economic conditions and transnational networks that sustain the practice of women who travel to another nation to give birth in order to secure citizenship in that nation for their children. Although considerable scholarly attention has been given to other forms of migration, relatively little scholarly attention has focused on what has been labelled as "birth tourism." Project findings will provide new insights and information that will contribute to broader understanding in a range of fields, such as transnational migration, immigration reception, race and place-making, and citizenship studies. The project also will foster greater knowledge about birthright citizenship's impacts on immigration politics, particularly in relation to racial formations and national belonging, and it will shed light on the changing geographies of migrant arrivals within established U.S. gateway cities. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

The doctoral student will conduct a case study that focuses on Chinese birth tourism in southern California. The project's objectives of this research are to gather basic factual information about the process of birth tourism; investigate local perceptions about birth tourism; and analyze how birth tourism influences ideas about race in neighborhoods and regional institutions in local, regional, and national contexts. The student will employ a range of ethnographic research techniques, including participant observation, interviews with key stakeholders and families (especially women) who engage in this practice, and analysis of relevant documents such as media reports and legal policies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on analysis of the Chinese birth tourism industry in southern California and the cities of Hong Kong, Taipei, and Guangzhou. It examined the process of Chinese birth tourism itself, perceptions of it for both individuals participating in birth tourism and those affected by it, and the wider politics associated with Chinese birth tourism in both regions. It sought to address why and how Chinese families engage in birth tourism, how southern California residents­—especially those of Asian descent—perceive reports of Chinese birth tourism, and how changes in birthright citizenship laws impact the geography of birth tourism. It did so by tracing key institutional, individual, and political responses to birth tourism in both regions. Birth tourism involves pregnant women giving birth abroad to secure foreign citizenship for their families in countries, like the U.S. and Canada, that allow jus soli birthright citizenship. A transnational industry around birth tourism has cropped up recently to facilitate it, especially between China and the U.S. Despite the increased visibility of Chinese birth tourism in the U.S. media and immigration debates, as well as in Chinese media, migration scholars know very little about it. Thus, this project explored the Chinese birth tourism industry ethnographically to better inform related discussions on immigration politics and birthright citizenship laws, as well as current policy debates on families with mixed legal status in the U.S.

To address the aforementioned questions, this project employed ethnographic and qualitative research methods, including interviews, participant observations, and analysis of relevant documents, in China and southern California, a key destination for Chinese birth tourists. Through these methods, this project produced the following findings: (1) the process of birth tourism, as facilitated by the agencies, involves an transnational circuit that connects actors from both the U.S. and abroad and is highly class-stratified; (2) the geography of birth tourism is highly dependent on transnational events and shifts outside the U.S., such as Hong Kong’s ban of similar practices in 2013; and (3) protests against Chinese birth tourism have negatively impacted both inter- and intra-racial relations in southern California. These findings advance several theoretical conversations within human geography and other social sciences and contribute to understandings of birthright citizenship’s impacts on immigration politics, particularly in relation to racial formations and national belonging. They also demonstrate the changing geographies of migrant arrivals within established U.S. gateway cities.
